Welcome to horsetailmatching’s documentation!¶

Module

Documentation for Horsetail Matching package

class horsetailmatching.UncertainParameter(distribution='uniform', mean=0, standard_deviation=1, pdf=None, lower_bound=-1, upper_bound=1)¶

Class for handling uncertain parameters in optimization under uncertainty problems using horsetail matching.

Parameters:
  • distribution (str) – distribution type of the uncertain parameter. Supported distributions are uniform, gaussian, custom (must provide a function to the pdf argument) [default uniform]
  • mean (double) – mean value of the distribution [default 0]
  • standard_deviation (double) – standard deviation of the distribution [default 1]
  • lower_bound (double) – lower bound of the distribution (overrides by mean and standard_devaition inputs) [default -1]
  • upper_bound (double) – upper bound of the distribution (overrides by mean and standard_devaition inputs) [default 1]
  • pdf (function) – pdf function to use distribution (overrides all other inputs)
evalPDF(u_values)¶

Returns the PDF of the uncertain parameter evaluated at the values provided in u_values.

Parameters:u_values (iterable) – values of the uncertain parameter at which to evaluate the PDF
getSample()¶

Returns a random sample of the uncertain variable according to its distribution using rejection sampling.

class horsetailmatching.HorsetailMatching(fqoi, uncertain_parameters, method='empirical', jacobian=None, ftarg=None, ftarg_u=None, ftarg_l=None, n_samples_prob=100, n_samples_int=10, n_integration_points=100, q_low=0, q_high=10, bw=None, alpha=100)¶

Class for using horsetail matching within an optimization. The main functionality is to create functions that return the horsetail matching metric (and optionally its gradient) that can be used with external optimizers.

Parameters:
  • fqoi (function) – function that returns the quantity of interest, it must take two ordered arguments - the value of the design variable vector and the value of the uncertainty vector.
  • uncertain_parameters_params (list) – list of Parameter objects that describe the uncertain inputs for the problem.
  • method (str) – method with which to evaluate the horsetil matching metric, can be ‘empirical’ or ‘kernel’ [default empirical].
  • jacobian (bool/function) – Only for method = ‘kernel’. Argument that specifies how to evaluate the gradient of the quantity of interest. If False no gradients are used, if True the fqoi should return a second argument g such that g_i = dq/dx_i. If a function, it should have the same signature as fqoi but return g. [default False]
  • ftarg (function) – function that returns the value of the target inverse CDF given a value in [0,1]. [default t(h) = 0]
  • ftarg_u (function) – under mixed uncertainties, function that returns the value of the target for the upper bound horsetail curve given a value in [0,1]. [default t_u(h) = 0]
  • ftarg_l (function) – under mixed uncertainties, function that returns the value of the target for the lower bound horsetail curve given a value in [0,1]. [default t_u(h) = 0]
  • n_samples_prob (int) – number of samples to take from the probabilsitic uncertainties. [default 100]
  • n_samples_int (int) – number of samples to take from the interval uncertainties. [default 10]
  • q_low (number) – Only for method=’kernel’. The lower bound on integration points when evaluating the metric using kernels [default 0]
  • q_high (number) – Only for method=’kernel’. The upper bound on integration points when evaluating the metric using kernels [default 10]
  • n_integration_points (number) – Only for method=’kernel’. Number of integration points to use between q_low and q_high. [default 100]
  • bw (number) – Only for method=’kernel’. The bandwidth used in the kernel function [by default is found the first time the metric is evaluated using Scott’s rule]
evalMetric(x, method=None, jac=None)¶

Evaluates the horsetail matching metric at given values of the design variables.

Parameters:
  • x (iterable) – values of the design variables
  • method (str) – method to use to evaluate the metric
